I just came across this video and, mostly, it's awesome and I agree.  The points where I disagree are: 1. Don't shoot down the innovators.  If someone can make your process more efficient, don't shame them, listen to them.  Study their variations and see if it can streamline the whole process.  Just like when using injection molding, spending a little more time up front with R&D can create a better product more efficiently.  2. As others have said, fans aren't the best solution for drying the products.  Especially without filters.  If you added a ducted HEPA filter, that would at least catch some contaminants.  Not a coronavirus but, other contaminants floating around.  As I said, overall a great video (as usual).

Hey guys. Destin.... Thanks for the endless amounts of inspiration. I'm not sure if anyone has come across this yet, but while I was looking for a replacement for the acetate cells (that have been very hard to find) I came across Cake Collars (a 33' roll. This one was 8" wide.) I determined that a 10" cut of that would fit the face shield frame well. (so 10"x8") I was able to get 39 from the roll for $28.  Maybe that's not a great price, but maybe there are better prices, and it's an option that worked. The thickness seemed fine to me, but the clarity was crystal. I had landed a bunch of Inkjet sheets with garbage clarity, since they need texture for ink. Finding purely clear acetate has been difficult.

FYI: A lack of N95 masks has led some people to wrap scarfs, etc around their face since it's "better than nothing". However, you can buy a nearly identical fabric at your local Home Depot in the air filter aisle. You're probably used to seeing the furnace filters in the cardboard box with the pleated material, but some larger furnaces require you to just buy the folded fabric and place the material between the fingers of a comb like structure. This material is about 3 feet long x 6 inches wide and even folded is about two inches thick in the box! So it's probably like 50 feet long unfolded! That's a LOT of masks for like $10 or whatever I paid (it was a while ago). Just trace the pattern of an actual mask, cut out and attach a rubber band! I'll take a HEPA filter material over an old tshirt anyday!

Ok, great point here!
The same issue that we got. This is how we solved it:

1. We created a FB group through which we informed people what we started doing, calling them to join the action.. Fast enough the group has grown 20k.
2. We created a Slack communication, putting 3 well informed doctors at the top of the communication. They must confirm the choice of materials and all design changes etc.
3. We transferred the interested people to the Slack communication and included them in the process. Created channels on Slack for helping of those who have a setup problems etc.
4. Bunch of volunteers connected to help the action, few people responsible for distribution organize them to collect the printed frames, distribute materials to the printers and help with the disinfection - supervised by some of the doctors.
5. Then the same guys help with the distribution of the prepared shield to the medical institutions.

- We improved the production (speed and quality), we changed the original Prusa model (removed the logo to speed-up - we needed to! , changed the hooks for the transparent shield - people were breaking the frames trying to assemble it , I made a video about how easy it is to assemble it now...).
- This works for the last 15 days! So far we have delivered (donated! ) thousands of shields and still going every day better that yesterday...

Thanks for all of those who are helping somehow. Huge respect.

Regards.

In these days and times, it's nice to remember President Kenedys words, slightly rewritten: "Ask not: What van my health care system do for me, ask: What can I do to keep health care staying alive!" Here in Denmark, our communities of Maker Space and Fab-Lab started producing face shields two weeks ago, and they asked all public offices to donate all their lamination pockets and overhead foils, and every one with a 3D printer is now working on the project. Every niche producer of beer and spirits have changed their objective to produce alcohol for sanitizing.
Half the World is stepping up to the plate, doing what they can to help their fellow humans, while the other half is whining about having to stay home for a few weeks, so I guess the Apokalypse has been postponed for a while now, and there's still hope for human kind :)
An other thing that has sprung out of this mayhem, is people who are volunteering to help those who are affected by the virus, by doing grocery shopping and other chores, so those in quarantine can stay at home, all organized by our local Red Cross and local FB groups.
It's heart warming to see how help is always given to those who needs it, even in the face of doom :)

I think your intentions are good, but this is nothing like what we use in the front line medical field.  Face masks are disposable equipment and are meant to fit more universally.  Rigid 3D printed and injection molded headbands do not fit universally and are much too costly to make.  I have a 3D printer and have used injection molding in medical prototypes.  You're wasting too much time.  The ones we have used for years have a sponge headband and velcro straps.  They are cost effective and are a throw away item.  Face shields are not meant to be sterile equipment, so better check with the local hospital as to your cleaning solutions so that it can be used in their hospital without causing contact allergies.  When one has a 3D printer one's solution is to 3D print the solution.  Much like having a hammer and everything looks like a nail.  3D printing is much too time consuming and costly for this solution.  And you would have to make too many different sizes to fit to each head shape.  A gap in the fit is not good.  Foam is much more economical and fits any size and contour head, man or woman.  It is much more comfortable, and cheap enough to just toss like disposable gloves.   Why change what has been working well for decades. You are overthinking the solution.  Your time may be better spent getting the public to wear surgical face masks when outside of the house. OK, one criticism, from someone who did all the disinfection for a small medical device company for 12 years; you really shouldn't be expediting the drying with fans unless you are in a cleanroom. Moving an excessive amount of air over a medical product forces any contamination in the room into contact with the product, rather than just the small amount that might fall onto the product from passive air currents. We went so far as to redirect the HVAC vent that was near the High Level Disinfection station.


Otherwise, all this talk of disinfection setup and execution brought back a lot of memories!

I'm a maker enrolled in my local community in Mallorca, Spain. We coordinate through a Telegram channel and a Google Doc spreadsheet where you inform of the number of items you have produced and if you are in need of material, and there's a couple of people that are in touch with the public health service, so they determine what is needed, and where. We are in almost total lockdown, so a few volunteers are allowed to collect items from maker's homes and send them to authorities, who desinfect them and send them to hospitals, local health services and whoever needs them.
We ask for no money. All we ask is that is you can, donate some plastic filament.

And It makes us proud to contribute.

We will get through this together (but isolated by the moment).

While I am aware there is a mask shortage, IF you are in a position to choose between a surgical mask and a cup shaped mask, please do use the cup shaped mask.  It provides a seal around your face while a surgical mask does not.   Surgical masks are better than nothing but they are not equivalent to the cup shaped dust masks, N95 or higher.  This is not just my personal opinion but also the CDC's official recommendation concerning masks.

Reminder that not all front line workers work in hospitals. The people at your local grocery store, your mail carriers, and bus drivers could all make good use of protective equipment, and are less likely to be included in state/federal supply packages.

Destin the disconnect is a huge part of the problem, and connecting is a huge part of the solution. We think there is a shortage of many supplies, but talking to relatives from two local hospitals, I found out one had plenty of face shields but no gowns, and the other had plenty of gowns but no face shields. Luckily I knew someone high enough up at one of the hospitals that they were able to get leadership at the two hospitals connected to discuss helping each other out. Perhaps nationally or globally we have more of what we need than we realize, and everything just needs to be shifted.

Relatives from the same two hospitals also connected and discovered that there was an entire community unaware of COVID-19 because of a language barrier. They asked people further up the chain to investigate, and within a few days they had doctors who spoke their language making radio spots and doing other community outreach.

I am one of the people undermining your efforts. I am extremely frustrated with what I see going on and I don't know who to talk to or what to do about it.



I work for an electrical company. I was on one of our commercial work sites today with a lot of other "essential" workers but nothing we are doing there is essential. (We are building a several new warehouses on this particular site.) The vast majority of our jobs are not essential. But because a small fraction of the jobs we do are essential there are no provisions for our companies to send people home. We are all still taking whatever work we can find, which is mostly not essential stuff. There are a bunch of different trades still working on the same site as well. I imagine many other commercial construction sites are still open as well.



So we are definitely undermining everyone's efforts to maintain separation and social distancing by going into people's houses and businesses for tons of trivial jobs. On our commercial sites there is no realistic way to maintain social distancing, and we constantly share tools, equipment, and machinery to get our jobs done. However the worst part is that now the job sites are telling us we can't work without PPE, which sounds good, except that means all of us on the job site are now fighting for the same non-existent supply of PPE that the medical community needs.



Please someone make this a story that someone who can do something about this can see. The 2 main points here are 1) most jobs an "essential" trade are asked to do are not essential, and 2) we are being put in a position where we need to try to get our hands on the same PPE that our medical community needs which will mean there is even less for them. I don't know why I haven't seen anyone talking about this issue.

Here in Curitiba (Paraná, Brazil), we're also printing tons of face shields. After about 7 days of printing non-stop, we got in contact with some big fatories, witch helped us get it injection molded finally.
I helped with all the logistics, we got support from the government (they gave us 2 cars and drivers to collect the printed parts from peoples' houses, deliver them filament to keep printing, and get the printed pieces to the warehouse where the sterilization is taking place). Now we have a very well coordenated team, spreadsheets with all the production and demand from the hospitals, also giving more priority to those receiving more cases of covid19.
Now the 3d printing community here is turning to the respirator split-valves.
Anyway, it's incredible to see the community working together, even more here (Curitiba is very well known for its very introverted citizens).

You know what's an even more effective shield?
Those who have been, but are no longer infected with Covid-19.

Also realize that MOST medical personnel are in the ages 20-50 and are healthy.
They have (as of current) a less than 0.1% fatality rate. Meaning it might actually be a good idea to "breed a super army" of immune medical practitioners.

Then of course you still have to ensure they don't carry the disease from one patient to another. And that is where the "no man's land" zone is set up.
If a patient believes they are infected, they need to go into this "no man's land" and get tested. In the zone, they are practically on their own. They go in, follow instructions and leave going back home again.
After a while, the test results are back and they get to know whether they are infected or not.
Not that it really matters because those who are getting severe symptoms will already KNOW they have it bad. They can go in the "no man's land" and pass on through to the other side to be treated.

Still, the virus itself isn't an all round killer. It kills those with certain pre-existing health conditions (very small numbers currently, but high "per capita" at 10%) and the elderly above 70 years of age with a fatality rate ranging from 14% to 22%.
For practically everyone else, the fatality rate is LESS than 0.1% so these people may just as well "buy the lottery ticket" and ride it through and thus taking out at least 65% of the population from the equation altogether.
Because once infected and your incubation time is over... You are immune. You don't infect others after this point unless you carry the infection from one patient to another.
But your body's immune system has already worked out the vaccine for the virus and will actively KILL the virus if it re-enters your body. So no face mask required.

I connected with a local surgeon and got the USA Prusa design approved with his hospital. I got a bunch of face shield frames to my local hospital and helped them coordinate with the local colleges and universities and libraries to get them all printing. My local hospital is sterilizing them on site with alcohol and then UVA, UVB, and UVC. Hospitals with their own Amazon Prime account and have 2 hour shipping out here so they ordered their own 3 ring binder clear dividers because they are already hole punched. Instead of a TPU printed strap to hold it on they are using tourniquets because they have an excess of them. With the dividers they don't need the bottom clip from the Prusa file which makes printing faster. I've since ran out of filament but I am now coordinating the colleges, University, and libraries and helping them trouble shoot and automate the process.
